docs.lead_paragraph: Are doctors supposed to live the lives of saints, public servants or working stiffs out to make a buck just like anyone else? The latest opinion in this old argument has just been articulated by a group of young doctors filing a class-action suit on behalf of medical students everywhere. The plaintiffs argue that while other professional school graduates negotiate freely with their first employers, graduating medical students are illegally hog-bound by a computerized national matching program that assigns them to the hospitals where they will spend the next several years, earning modest, nonnegotiable salaries for punishing work hours.
docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuber Cases column discusses class-action suit filed by group of young doctors arguing that while other professional school graduates can negotiate freely with first employers, medical school students are bound by computerized national matching program that assigns them to hospitals where they earn modest, nonnegotiable salaries for punishing work hours (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of deaths in America from lupus has risen sharply in recent years, particularly among middle-aged black women, according to a report released this month by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The number of deaths linked to lupus rose to 1,406 in 1998 from 879 in 1979, according to a report in the center's journal, The Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report. The death rate among black women rose by 70 percent.
docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in Morbidity and Mortality Weekly, reports sharp rise in number of deaths in America from lupus, particularly among middle-aged black women (M)

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: Aspirin may help prevent heart disease in more ways than was thought, according to a study released yesterday in the journal Circulation. People originally took aspirin for pain and inflammation. But in recent years a small, a regular dose of aspirin has been recommended to many people because of the discovery that it also reduces blood clotting, cutting the risk of a heart attack.
docs.abstract: Study conducted by Dr Patrick Vallance of University College London, published in journal Circulation, finds aspirin's anti-inflammatory properties can benefit heart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two new case studies illustrate the strange perils that can lurk in simple things, like takeoffs and tea. The first, to be described this week at the conference of the American Neurology Society, deals with a 61-year-old man whose face became paralyzed on one side during two plane trips. In both cases, the paralysis, called baroparesis, set in about 90 minutes after takeoff and cleared up after the plane landed.
docs.abstract: Brief descriptions of two case studies relating to nervous system: in first case, man's face became paralyzed on one side during two plane trips as result of blockage in middle ear, which caused pressure to shut down facial nerve; ventilation tube was inserted until blockage was surgically removed; in second case, Austrian man who switched from drinking up to gallon of black tea a day to Earl Grey tea developed muscle cramps, numbness and blurred vision; Earl Grey contains essence of bergamot oil, which could interfere with absorption of potassium; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Colorize your diet. That is the latest advice from nutrition experts who have studied the health-promoting properties of the vast spectrum of colorful fruits and vegetables now available throughout the country. Two recently published books -- ''What Color Is Your Diet?'' (Regan Books, $25), by Dr. David Heber, director of the Center for Human Nutrition at the University of California at Los Angeles, with Susan Bowerman, a dietitian, and ''The Color Code'' (Hyperion, $22.95) by Dr. James A. Joseph, Dr. Daniel A. Nadeau and Anne Underwood -- emphasize the importance of increasing consumption of fruits and vegetables, and the need to choose broadly among the richly colored options.

headline.main: The Color of Nutrition: Fruits and Vegetables

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column, in light of new books What Color Is Your Diet? by Dr David Heber and The Color Code by Dr James A Joseph, Dr Daniel A Nadeau and Anne Underwood, on health benefits of increasing consumption of richly colored fruits and vegetables; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Patients don't need to go into the operating room hungry and thirsty anymore, but a lot of them still do, according to a survey that tracked how long they were being asked to fast before surgery. The custom of allowing neither food nor water after midnight became established decades ago to help prevent patients from breathing food into their lungs while under general anesthesia. But as anesthesia techniques improved, the danger receded. In 1999, the American Society of Anesthesiologists put out new guidelines, permitting clear liquids up to two hours before surgery, a light breakfast up to six hours before and a heavier meal eight hours before.
docs.abstract: American Society of Anesthesiologists survey, published in American Journal of Nursing, finds that large number of hospital patients still fast before surgery longer than recommended under guidelines issued in 1999; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Michael J. Fox's celebrity can do more than raise money for Parkinson's research. It may also help open an avenue of research that scientists have long wanted to explore. Mr. Fox, it turns out, was one of four people who worked on a production crew at a television studio in Vancouver, British Columbia, in the late 1970's and developed Parkinson's disease. Given that only 125 people worked on the crew in those years -- including actors, directors, writers, production people and technicians -- the number of cases seems extraordinary.
docs.abstract: Article on research into whether clusters of Parkinson's disease victims are result of environmental factors or viruses; actor Michael J Fox is one of four people who worked on production crew at television studio in Vancouver, British Columbia, in late 1970's who developed Parkinson's disease; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, after giving up his television series ''Spin City,'' Michael J. Fox created a medical research foundation that is already renowned for its fast-paced disbursements to scientists. Since April of last year, the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research has given out nearly $17 million to help finance 57 studies. The foundation supports studies covering everything from gene therapy to the effects of caffeine on Parkinson's disease. It has recently dedicated $4.4 million to developing stem cell lines -- some derived from embyonic or fetal tissue, some from adult tissue -- that could be implanted in the brains of Parkinson's patients to replace the dopamine-producing cells they have lost.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH -- Michael J. Fox; A 'Lucky Man' Puts His Celebrity to Work

docs.abstract: Excerpts from conversation with actor Michael J Fox, whose foundation supports variety of studies on Parkinson's disease; foundation recently dedicated $4.4 million to developing stem cell lines that would replace dopamine-producing cells Parkinson's patients have lost; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Five years ago, R. Scott Bromley, then 57, was returning from a trip to Sicily with friends when he felt a nagging pain in his right side. He was scheduled for an annual checkup the next day, and he learned from a blood test that his liver enzymes were elevated. Not a big drinker, Mr. Bromley, a New York architect, told the doctor that while in Italy, ''You have a little wine before dinner on the piazza, a little wine during dinner, a little wine after dinner,'' and suggested maybe that was the cause of the unusual numbers.

headline.main: More Are Finding Permanent Cures for Hepatitis C

docs.abstract: Article on new treatments for hepatitis C which, unlike hepatitis A and B, has no vaccine and can lead to cirrhosis or cancer; new cases have decline 80 percent in last decade but number of patients is rising because disease takes so long to progress; photo (M)
